Articles.Content: One important thing that hasn't been made clear just yet is what happens if you transmit data about a science experiment AND return with the experiment itself. Is that even possible? And if it is, how would it tally the points? Because if it isn't possible, there will need to be some sort of checks-and-balances system in place to prevent players from completely and utterly dead-ending their science potential by radioing in all of their results and being able to only get paltry returns for repeat missions that actually do return a sample. I wouldn't be surprised if Squad already has something in place to account for this, but if not, well, point of consideration if nothing else.

I heard they're working out exploits and such so people cant abuse the science, so it will hopefully be balanced upon release. I'm sure it will be revised and fiddled with later on if there are any problems.

The way I've been seeing it so far on the live stream going on now...

is that when you transmit it clears the storage ... so you can take more readings... if you're going to transmit then it transmits everything... you can't pick and choose what gets transmitted. I believe if you then landed then since the "science storage" was cleared that you wouldn't get anything from it and only get the amount from transmitting.

That's how I see it working right now. It is in testing and all of that is subject to change.

In this case the interesting question is, whether it gives more "science points" when you bring back the data to Kerbin (compared to transmitting it via radio),

or if it doesnÃ‚Â´t matter whether you transmit the data via radio comm or try to carry it back to Kerbin

In the livestream yesterday i noticed that the transmit button has a percentage under it, I only saw it at either 100% or 50%, it might depend on how much data and/or the type of data/sample. Also transmitting uses power and you dont get to start with batteries or solar panels.

Here's a scenario that illustrates my question: say you take a reading on the Mun's surface that's worth 150 science, and you radio it back for 20% of that (30). Then you do the same experiment again at the same spot and actually bring the unit back to Kerbin for salvage. Would the salvage be worth only a small fraction of the original 150, or would it be worth a meaningful chunk since it was the first time that particular piece of research had a physical return to Kerbin?

I think a nice way to balance that would be to count "sample return" as a separate point bonus. However, if you radio AND sample return, apply a penalty to simulate the decreasing marginal utility of doing the same experiment.

Well I guess we'll just have to wait and find out! I hope there aren't any diminishing returns like the one you're describing otherwise I probably won't be transmitting very much data back. I'm also curious about how satellites will work with science; will a solar panel, a thermometer and and antenna allow me to farm science?

I think my own way of doing it would be thus: if you radio in an experiment and return the sample, it should overall between them be worth 75% to 90% of a return-only mission depending on the experiment type. That would give a fair trade-off between radioing something back and still getting science as a hedge against failure to return the experiment properly to Kerbin, and taking the risk of the whole experiment being completely worthless because you didn't radio anything in at all and the experiment got destroyed before you could salvage it.

It's already been confirmed that no, you can't farm science like that. You get diminishing returns from running the same experiment over and over again, presumably giving you 0 science once you've done it enough times.
